--------------------------------------------------------------------
### 1.   Frequencies of the two waves in the laboratory

#### Wave seen by the moving wall  

For a stationary source and a moving observer the classical Doppler law
gives  

\[
\boxed{\;\omega _w=\omega\left(1+\beta\right)} ,
\]
because the wall “receives’’ the incident wave with a higher pitch:
\[
\omega_w=\omega\frac{v+V}{v}= \omega(1+\beta).
\]

#### Reflected wave returned to the laboratory  

After reflection the wall behaves as a *moving source*.   
When a source recedes from a fixed detector the observed frequency is  

\[
\omega_{\rm ref}= \omega_w\frac{v}{v-V}
               =\omega(1+\beta)\frac{1}{1-\beta}.
\]

Therefore the reflected wave that reaches the laboratory has angular
frequency  

\[
\boxed{\;\omega_r=\omega\frac{1+\beta}{1-\beta}}\tag{1}
\]

while the directly arriving incident wave keeps its original frequency
\(\omega\).

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### 2.   Beats heard in the laboratory

Both waves coexist in the room, so their superposition contains a term
that oscillates with the **difference** of the two angular frequencies,

\[
\Delta\omega = |\omega_r-\omega|
              =\omega\!\left[\frac{1+\beta}{1-\beta}-1\right]
              =\omega\frac{2\beta}{1-\beta}.      \tag{2}
\]

Consequently the beat **frequency** (in cycles per second) is  

\[
\boxed{
    f_{\rm beat}= \frac{\Delta\omega}{2\pi}
                = f\,\frac{2\beta}{1-\beta}},\qquad 
     f=\frac{\omega}{2\pi}.
\] 

For \(\beta\ll 1\) this reduces to the familiar approximation
\(f_{\rm beat}\simeq 2\beta f\).

---

### (a)   Horizontal range – no air resistance  

For a projectile launched from level ground with speed \(v_{0}\) making an angle \(\theta\) with the horizontal,

\[
\begin{aligned}
x(t)&=v_{0}\cos\theta\,t ,\\[2mm]
y(t)&=v_{0}\sin\theta\,t-\frac12gt^{2}.
\end{aligned}
\]

The impact occurs when \(y(T)=0\;(T>0)\),

\[
0=v_{0}\sin\theta\,T-\frac12gT^{2}\quad\Longrightarrow\qquad 
T=\frac{2v_{0}\sin\theta}{g}.
\]

Hence the **range** is  

\[
\boxed{\displaystyle
R_{0}=x(T)=v_{0}\cos\theta\;\frac{2v_{0}\sin\theta}{g}
      =\frac{v_{0}^{2}\,\sin 2\theta}{g}}
\tag{1}
\]


--------------------------------------------------------------------

### (b)   Simple kinetic‑theory model for aerodynamic drag  

Consider a body moving through still air whose molecules have number density  
\(n\) and molecular mass \(m_{\rm mol}\); the mass density of the gas is   
\(\rho=n\,m_{\rm mol}\). In a short interval \({\rm d}t\)

* volume swept out by the projected frontal area \(A\) : \(A\,|v|\:{\rm d}t\);
* number of molecules encountered                : \( nA|v|\,{\rm d}t\);
* each molecule, initially at rest, acquires forward momentum  
  \(m_{\rm mol}|v|\) after an elastic collision (perfectly “sticking’’ case).

Total change of momentum transferred to the body per unit time is therefore  

\[
F_{\rm drag}=-
\underbrace{nA|v|}_{\text{collision rate}}\;
\underbrace{m_{\rm mol}|v|}_{\text{momentum gain per hit}}
=
-\rho A |v|\,v .
\]

In practice one introduces a dimensionless shape factor \(C_{d}\sim {\cal O}(1)\)
to account for imperfect reflection and turbulence, obtaining the familiar **quadratic‐drag law**

\[
\boxed{\displaystyle 
\mathbf{F}_{\!{\rm drag}}=-\frac12\,C_{d}\,\rho\,A\,v^{2}\,
\hat{\mathbf v}}
\tag{2}
\]

where \(\hat{\mathbf v}\) points along the instantaneous velocity vector.


--------------------------------------------------------------------

### (c)   Motion under Stokes (linear) drag  

For a solid sphere of radius \(R\) moving slowly enough that the Reynolds number
is \(\ll 1\), the drag force is well described by Stokes’ law  

\[
\mathbf{F}_{\!{\rm air}}=-6\pi\eta R\,\mathbf v ,
\qquad\gamma\equiv\frac{6\pi\eta R}{m},
\]

with \(\eta\) the dynamic viscosity of air and \(\gamma\) having dimensions of inverse time.

#### Equations of motion  

\[
\begin{cases}
\dot v_x = -\gamma v_x, \\[2pt]
\dot v_y = -g-\gamma v_y .
\end{cases}
\]

With the initial conditions \(v_x(0)=v_{0}\cos\theta\),
\(v_y(0)=v_{0}\sin\theta\) the solutions are  

\[
\boxed{
\begin{aligned}
v_x(t)&=v_{0}\cos\theta\,e^{-\gamma t},\\[4pt]
v_y(t)&=\Bigl(v_{0}\sin\theta+\frac{g}{\gamma}\Bigr)e^{-\gamma t}-\frac{g}{\gamma}.
\end{aligned}}
\tag{3}
\]

Integrating once more yields the coordinates  

\[
\boxed{
\begin{aligned}
x(t)&=\frac{v_{0}\cos\theta}{\gamma}\bigl(1-e^{-\gamma t}\bigr),\\[4pt]
y(t)&=\frac{v_{0}\sin\theta+\dfrac{g}{\gamma}}{\gamma}
        \bigl(1-e^{-\gamma t}\bigr)-\frac{g}{\gamma}\,t .
\end{aligned}}
\tag{4}
\]

These formulas reduce smoothly to the vacuum results when \(\gamma\!\to\!0\):
using \(e^{-\gamma t}=1-\gamma t+\mathcal O(\gamma ^2)\),

\[
x(t)\simeq v_{0}\cos\theta\,t,\qquad
y(t)\simeq v_{0}\sin\theta\,t-\tfrac12 gt,
\]

as required.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
#### Flight time and first–order correction to the range  

The landing instant \(T\) satisfies \(y(T)=0\):

\[
\left(v_{0}\sin\theta+\frac{g}{\gamma}\right)
\bigl(1-e^{-\gamma T}\bigr)=gT .
\tag{5}
\]

When the drag is weak (\(\gamma T\ll 1\)) we expand the exponential:
\(e^{-\gamma T}=1-\gamma T+\tfrac12(\gamma T)^{2}+…\).
Keeping terms up to first order in \(\gamma\) leads to  

\[
T\simeq T_{0}-\frac{\gamma}{2}T_{0}^{2},
\qquad
T_{0}\equiv\frac{2v_{0}\sin\theta}{g},
\tag{6}
\]

so the flight time is shortened slightly compared with the vacuum value.

Using Eq.(4) for the horizontal coordinate and expanding again,

\[
x(T)=\frac{v_{0}\cos\theta}{\gamma}
       \bigl(1-e^{-\gamma T}\bigr)
     \simeq v_{0}\cos\theta\,T-\frac12\gamma v_{0}\cos\theta\,T^{2}.
\]

Substituting the approximation (6) for \(T\) and discarding all terms
of order \(\gamma^{2}\) finally gives the **horizontal range including the
first‑order Stokes correction**

\[
\boxed{
\begin{aligned}
R &\equiv x(T) \\
&\simeq 
\underbrace{\frac{v_{0}^{2}\sin 2\theta}{g}}_{R_{0}}
\;-\;
\underbrace{\frac{4\gamma\,v_{0}^{3}\sin^{2}\theta\cos\theta}{g^{2}}}_{\Delta R } .
\end{aligned}}
\tag{7}
\]

Writing \(\gamma=6\pi\eta R/m\),

\[
\boxed{\displaystyle
\Delta R
    =-\frac{24\pi\eta R}{m}\,
      \frac{v_{0}^{3}\sin^{2}\theta\cos\theta}{g^{2}} } .
\]

The sign is negative, i.e. the presence of even a modest viscous drag always reduces the attainable range. When \(\eta\to0\) or \(R\to0\) the correction vanishes and Eq.(7) reverts to the ideal ballistic range (1), confirming consistency.

Goal: find condition on beam energy E such that exists kinematic arrangement leading to W at rest in lab.

Momentum magnitude in top rest frame: p_* = λ^{1/2}(M^2,m1^2,m2^2)/(2M). With m2=0 gives p_* = (M^2 - m1^2)/(2M) = (m_t^2 - m_W^2)/(2 m_t) = (m_t/2)-(m_W^2/(2 m_t)).

If θ*=0 (cosθ*=+1): p_* + β_T E*_W =0 → impossible since positive quantities give negative β_T. So only possibility is θ*=π (emitted backwards relative to top motion). So W emitted directly opposite to top flight direction in top rest frame.

Condition: β_T = p_*/E*_W .

Square both sides:

Recall identity: (A+B)^2 - (A-B)^2 = 4AB.

Take A=m_t^2, B=m_W^2. Then numerator = 4 m_t^2 m_W^2.

Therefore (m_t/E)^2 = 4 m_t^2 m_W^2 / (m_t^2 + m_W^2)^2.

Cancel m_t^2 both sides: divide both sides by m_t^2:

When a \(t\bar t\) pair is created the two tops share the total energy equally,

\[
E_t=E,\qquad 
|\mathbf p_t|=p=\sqrt{E^{2}-m_t^{2}} ,
\]
so that the top moves with velocity  

\[
\beta_T=\frac{p}{E}
      =\sqrt{1-\left(\frac{m_t}{E}\right)^{2}},\qquad   
\gamma_T=\frac{E}{m_t}.
\]

---

### Decay of a single top

In the rest frame of the top (\(*\)-frame) the decay  

\[
t\;\longrightarrow\;W^{+}+b,
\]

with \(m_b\simeq0\), gives

\[
E_W^\ast   =\frac{m_t^{2}+m_W^{2}}{2m_t},\qquad    
p_W^\ast   =\frac{m_t^{2}-m_W^{2}}{2m_t}.
\]

Choose the \(z\)-axis along the top‐momentum in the lab.  
If the \(W\) makes an angle \(\theta^\ast\) with respect to this axis in the top rest frame,
its four‑vector in the lab is obtained by a boost of rapidity \(\beta_T\):

\[
\begin{aligned}
E_W &=\gamma_T\bigl(E_W^\ast+\beta_T p_W^\ast\cos\theta^\ast\bigr),\\[2pt]
p_{Wz}&=\gamma_T\bigl(p_W^\ast\cos\theta^\ast+\beta_T E_W^\ast\bigr),\\[2pt]
p_{W\perp}&=p_W^\ast\sin\theta^\ast .
\end{aligned}
\]

To have the \(W\) at rest in the laboratory we need simultaneously  

\[
p_{W\perp}=0,\qquad p_{Wz}=0 .
\]

Since \(p_W^\ast\neq0\) (the top is heavier than the \(W\)), the transverse condition forces  

\[
\sin\theta^\ast =0\Longrightarrow \theta^\ast =0\ {\rm or }\ \pi .
\]

Only the “backward’’ choice \(\theta^\ast=\pi\) can make the longitudinal momentum vanish:
\[
-p_W^\ast+\beta_T E_W^\ast =0\quad\Rightarrow\quad 
\beta_T=\frac{p_W^\ast}{E_W^\ast}
       =\frac{m_t^{2}-m_W^{2}}{m_t^{2}+m_W^{2}}\; .
\]

---

### Required beam energy

Insert the expression for \(\beta_T\),

\[
\sqrt{1-\Bigl(\frac{m_t}{E}\Bigr)^{2}}
     =\frac{m_t^{2}-m_W^{2}}{m_t^{2}+m_W^{2}},
\]

square and solve for \(E\):

\[
\begin{aligned}
\Bigl(\frac{m_t}{E}\Bigr)^{2}
&=1-
    \frac{\bigl(m_t^{2}-m_W^{2}\bigr)^{2}}
         {\bigl(m_t^{2}+m_W^{2}\bigr)^{2}}
 =\frac{4m_t^{2}m_W^{2}}{\bigl(m_t^{2}+m_W^{2}\bigr)^{2}}, \\[4pt]
E^{2}&=
\frac{\bigl(m_t^{2}+m_W^{2}\bigr)^{2}}{4m_W^{2}},\\[4pt]
\boxed{\,E=\dfrac{m_t^{2}+m_W^{2}}{2m_W}\, } .
\end{aligned}
\]

Using the approximation stipulated in the problem, \(m_t=2m_W\),

\[
E=\frac{(2m_W)^{2}+m_W^{2}}{2m_W}
   =\frac{5}{2}m_W
   =\frac{5}{4}m_t .
\]

---

## Answer

Yes – a \(W\) boson can be produced at rest in the laboratory, but only for a single, finely tuned beam energy. Neglecting all masses except \(m_t\) and \(m_W\) (with \(m_t=2m_W\)), the necessary beam energy per lepton is  

\[
\boxed{\,E=\frac{5}{4}\,m_t
        =\frac{m_t^{2}+m_W^{2}}{2m_W}\, } .
\]

Any deviation of \(E\) above or below this value makes it kinematically impossible for a \(W\) to be stationary in the lab.

assistantfinalThe particle initially moves on a **circular** orbit of radius \(r_{0}\) under the attractive central force  

\[
\mathbf {F}(r)= -\,\frac{k}{r^{2}}\;\hat{\mathbf r},
\qquad   k>0 .
\]

---

### 1. Conditions for the original circular orbit  

*Radial equilibrium*

\[
\frac{mv_{\rm c}^{2}}{r_{0}}=\frac{k}{r_{0}^{2}}
        \Longrightarrow 
v_{\rm c}^{2}= \frac{k}{mr_{0}},
\tag{1}
\]

where \(v_{\rm c}\) is the constant orbital speed.

*Angular momentum*

\[
L=m r_{0}v_{\rm c}=m r_{0}\sqrt{\frac{k}{mr_{0}}}
      =\sqrt{mk r_{0}} .
\tag{2}
\]

*Mechanical energy*  
(The potential associated with \(\mathbf F\) is \(U(r)=-k/r\))

\[
E_i =\tfrac12 mv_{\rm c}^{2}+U(r_0)
     =\frac{k}{2r_{0}}-\frac{k}{r_{0}}
     =-\frac{k}{2r_{0}}<0 .
\tag{3}
\]

Hence the initial orbit is bounded (\(E_i<0\)), indeed it is a circle.

--------------------------------------------------------------------

### 2. Sudden decrease of the force constant  

At some instant the constant changes abruptly from \(k\) to 

\[
k'\equiv\frac{k}{2}.
\]

No external impulse acts on the particle, therefore both its **velocity**
and its **angular momentum** remain exactly what they were just before the change:
\(v=v_{\rm c},\; L={\rm const}\).

The new potential is now  

\[
U'(r)=-\frac{k'}{r}= -\frac{k}{2r}.
\]

Consequently the total mechanical energy immediately after the change is  

\[
\begin{aligned}
E_f &=\tfrac12 m v_{\rm c}^{2}+U'(r_0)\\[2mm]
    &=\frac{k}{2r_{0}}-\frac{k}{2r_{0}}\\[2mm]
    &=0 .
\end{aligned}
\tag{4}
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------

### 3. Interpretation of the zero‑energy state  

In the Kepler problem the specific (per–unit‑mass) mechanical energy  

\[
\varepsilon =\frac{v^{2}}{2}-\frac{k'}{mr}
\]

determines the type of conic section traced out by the particle:

| \(\varepsilon\) | Conic |
|-----------------|-------|
| \(\varepsilon <0\) | ellipse (circle is a special case) |
| \(\varepsilon =0\) | parabola |
| \(\varepsilon >0\) | hyperbola |

Since Eq.(4) shows that \(\varepsilon =0\) after the sudden reduction,
the resulting trajectory is a **parabola**, i.e. a marginally escaping orbit.

Equivalently, one may invoke the vis‑viva relation  

\[
v^{2}= \mu\!\left(\frac{2}{r}-\frac{1}{a}\right),
\qquad \mu\equiv\frac{k'}{m},
\]

with the post‑change parameters \(\mu =k/(2m)\) and \(v=v_{\rm c}\).
Substituting \(v^{2}=k/(mr_{0})\) and solving for the semimajor axis \(a\),

\[
\frac{k}{mr_{0}}=
\frac{k}{2m}\Bigl(\frac{2}{r_{0}}-\frac{1}{a}\Bigr)
\Longrightarrow a\to\infty ,
\]

which again signals a parabolic orbit (\(e=1\)).

--------------------------------------------------------------------
\[
\boxed{
\text{When }k\text{ is instantaneously halved, the particle’s total energy becomes zero, }
\Rightarrow\text{its subsequent path is a parabola.}
}
\]

\[

\qquad 
k=\frac{GM}{R^{3}}
      =\frac{4\pi G\rho }{3}.
\]

In a frame that co–rotates with the planet the equations of motion contain,
besides the true gravity, the fictitious centrifugal acceleration  
\( {\bf a}_{cf}= \boldsymbol{\omega}\times(\boldsymbol{\omega}\times{\bf r})\)
and the Coriolis term \(2\boldsymbol{\omega}\times{\bf v}\).
Because the particle is constrained to move **along the tunnel**, the Coriolis
force produces only a reaction pressure on the wall; it does not affect the
component of the motion parallel to the tunnel.   
Consequently the longitudinal dynamics are governed solely by the sum of the
radial part of gravity and the component of the centrifugal acceleration that
lies along the tunnel.

---

### 1.   Tunnel along the rotation axis (the “polar” tunnel)

All points of the tunnel lie on the rotation axis (\(s=0\)), therefore the
centrifugal term vanishes completely :

\[
\ddot{x}+kx=0 .
\]

Hence the angular frequency and the period are  

\[
\boxed{\;\Omega_{\rm pol}= \sqrt{k}
       =\sqrt{\dfrac{GM}{R^{3}}}\;}
,\qquad    
\boxed{\;T_{\rm pol}= \frac{2\pi}{\sqrt{k}}\;} .
\]

Using the mean Earth data  

\[
R=6.371\times10^{6}\ {\rm m},\qquad 
g_{0}=9.81\ {\rm m\,s^{-2}},\qquad 
k=g_0/R\simeq1.540\times10^{-6}\ {\rm s^{-2}},
\]

we obtain  

\[
T_{\rm pol}= \frac{2\pi}{\sqrt{1.540\times10^{-6}}}
            \approx 5.07\times10^{3}\ {\rm s}
            \approx 84.5\ {\rm min}.     
\]

---

### 2.   Tunnel lying in the equatorial plane (ends on the equator)

points of the equator.

its distance from the rotation axis is \(s=|x|\).

\[
\ddot{x}+ (k-\omega^{2})\,x =0 ,
\]

\[
\boxed{\;\Omega_{\rm eq}= \sqrt{k-\omega^{2}}\;},
\qquad
\boxed{\;T_{\rm eq}= \frac{2\pi}{\sqrt{k-\omega^{2}}}\;}.
\]

2\pi/T_{\text{day}}=7.292\times10^{-5}\ {\rm rad\,s^{-1}}\),

\[
\omega^{2}=5.31\times10^{-9}\ {\rm s^{-2}},\qquad
k-\omega^{2}=1.535\times10^{-6}\ {\rm s^{-2}},
\]
\[

smooth guide the particle cannot stay confined to the exact straight line;

behaviour altogether.

requirement is stricter for the equatorial tunnel because any friction couples
to the Coriolis effect and quickly spoils the pure SHM.

* Corresponding period  

\[
\displaystyle T(L)=\frac{2\pi mR^{2}}{L}.
\]

* Small radial oscillations  

\[
\displaystyle \delta(t)=A\cos\!\bigl(\Omega t\bigr)+B\sin\!\bigl(\Omega t\bigr),
\qquad 
\Omega^{2}= \frac{GM}{R^{3}}-\frac{21b}{mR^{5}} .
\]

* Azimuthal evolution (to first order in \(\delta\))

\[
\displaystyle 
\varphi(t)=\frac{L}{mR^{2}}\,t
          -\frac{2L}{mR^{3}\Omega}\,A\sin(\Omega t)+\text{const}.
\]

These formulas apply directly to the relativistic case upon inserting
\(b=(GM/L^{2})(L^{2}/mc^{2})=GM L^{2}/(m c^{2})\).
